Description: Mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; back rubbed, with outline of clypeus and prothorax still faintly visible; not accurate profile of back, which is flat across top; at side, thick legs simply and crudely modelled, with undercut triangle; underside incised with representation of two animals, arranged one above the other: winged horse attacked by a lion; longitudinally pierced; in paste of soft texture, bright blue in colour; surface quite eroded.
Curator's comments: Lion attacking a prey is a recurrent theme on Egyptian blue scarabs and scaraboids produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Eastern Greece, and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 121-127, type XXXIV, subtype C1-10, see especially C9 for this piece). This group varies in style with other animal representations on Naukratite scarabs and scaraboids - animals with more elongated bodies, finer incisions - giving the impression that they are of better workmanship (Gorton 1996, 122). This type of representation can be paralleled to Archaic Greek gems, with single oval line incised round edge. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implication for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 140)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 125-126, type XXXIV C9)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.11) (phase 3)
